acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This collection was deposited in the University of Virginia Library by Archibald G. Robertson of Richmond, Virginia, on October 21, 1938. The collection was given to the University of Virginia Library on June 27, 1980, by Mrs. Marvyn W. Robertson of Richmond, Virginia; John S. Beard of Shillington, Pennsylvania; Archibald G. Robertson of Richmond, Virginia; Alexander F. Robertson, Jr., of Staunton, Virginia; George M. Cochran of Staunton, Virginia; Alexander R. Beard of St. Davids, Pennsylvania; and Margaret Cochran Hinch of Staunton, Virginia.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Archibald Stuart was born on March 19, 1757, in Staunton, Virginia, the son of Alexander and Mary (Patterson) Stuart. He was educated at the Augusta Academy, the College of William and Mary, and studied law with Thomas Jefferson following the American Revolution. He then began practicing law in the Shenandoah Valley and served as a judge of the General court of Virginia from 1800 until just before his death.

Stuart was also active in politics as a leader of the Jeffersonian Democrats in Virginia. He was elected to the Virginia House of Delegates from Botetourt County in 1783 and was particularly active in the reform of the state court system and the reorganization of state government. He also played a prominent role in the ratification of the new federal Constitution in 1788, was a member of the Virginia-Kentucky Boundary Commission in 1795, a member of the Virginia Senate at the turn of the century, and was a presidential elector for the Jeffersonian Democrats from 1800 to 1824. Stuart married Eleanor Briscoe, the daughter of Gerard Briscoe of Frederick County, Virginia, in May, 1791, and died in Staunton on July 11, 1832.

Briscoe Gerard Baldwin was born on January 18, 1789, in Winchester, Virginia, the eldest son of Cornelius Baldwin and Mary Briscoe, another daughter of Gerard Briscoe. He attended William and Mary College and later studied law under Judge William Daniel in Cumberland County, Virginia. During 1818-1820 he served in the Virginia House of Delegates as representative for Augusta County; and, in 1829-1830 was a member of the constitutional convention. He returned to the House of Delegates during 1841-1842. On January 29, 1842, Baldwin was elected a member of the Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia and held that position until his death on May 18, 1852.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of ca. 4,500 items (19 Hollinger boxes, ca. 8 linear shelf feet), 1764-1884, the papers of Archibald Stuart (1757-1832) and Briscoe Gerard Baldwin (1789-1852) of Staunton, Virginia. The collection is comprised chiefly of correspondence and legal and financial papers pertaining to the legal practice of Archibald Stuart and Briscoe G. Baldwin. These papers concern various legal issues, including land patents, wills, land deeds, land surveys, accounts, slave transactions, and criminal and civil suits. Also included in the collection are letters from Martha S. Baldwin to her husband, Briscoe G. Baldwin, containing news of family and friends, and correspondence of Alexander Hugh Holmes Stuart, son of Archibald Stuart, some of which concerns the Whig party and Presidential elections.

Also included in the collection are military papers, primarily signed oaths to serve in the Continental Army, 1782-1783, and documents verifying military service for pensions. Other topics mentioned in the collection include student life at the College of William and Mary, Virginia Military Institute, and the University of Virginia; temperance parties; a law school operated by Briscoe G. Baldwin in Staunton; and meetings of the Virginia Assembly. There is also a copy of a land grant signed by Thomas Jefferson and an answer to a bill of complaint given by John Wayles as an attorney in the case of Faroll and Jones vs Horbort. Principal correspondents include Archibald Stuart, Briscoe G. Baldwin, Martha S. Baldwin, Alexander Hugh Holmes Stuart, and John Brown, Baldwin's father-in-law. Other correspondents include Charles Francis Adams, Philip Pendleton Barbour, James Breckinridge, Arthur Spicer Brockenbrough, William H. Cabell, Augustus Alexander Chapman, William Daniel, Jr., James H. Dooley, Thomas Walker Gilmer, Chapman Johnson, George Tucker and Henry St. George Tucker.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged chronologically, within two series: Series I: Correspondence and Series II: Legal and Financial Papers, including Miscellaneous Papers . A checklist has been prepared of the correspondence and is arranged in alphabetical order by last name of correspondent.
